note.p: Winfield Scott Featherston was a U.S. congressman from Mississippi and a general in the Confederate Army during the Civil War.

Born on August 8, 1820, near Murfreesboro, Tennessee, Featherston volunteered for militia service as a teenager during the Second Creek War in Alabama in 1836. After that conflict, he moved to Mississippi and studied law, becoming a practicing attorney in 1840. Soon after, Featherston became involved in local politics, and won a seat to the U.S. House of Representatives for Mississippi in 1846. He served until 1851, then returned to his home in Houston, Mississippi, after losing reelection in 1850. In 1856, he moved to Holly Springs and opened a successful law firm.

Featherston remained a political figure in Mississippi, particularly during the secession movement following Abraham Lincoln’s election to the presidency in 1860. He traveled to Kentucky, as an agent of Mississippi, to encourage secession in that state. When the war broke out in 1861, Featherston received a commission as a colonel and took command of the Seventeenth Mississippi Infantry Regiment. Sent to Virginia, he led Confederate troops at the First Battle of Bull Run and Ball’s Bluff in Virginia. He was promoted to brigadier general in March 1862 and participated in several major engagements that year, including the Seven Days Campaign outside of Richmond, the Second Battle of Bull Run, Antietam, and Fredericksburg.

In early 1863, Featherston was transferred to Mississippi. He commanded a brigade during the Vicksburg campaign, seeing combat at Champion’s Hill, and participated in the Atlanta Campaign in 1864. He remained with General John Bell Hood’s army during the disastrous campaign into Tennessee in late 1864, and commanded a brigade in General Joseph E. Johnston’s army during the final weeks of the war in the Carolinas. He surrendered to Union troops in late April 1865, was paroled shortly afterwards, and returned to Holly Springs, Mississippi.

Featherston immediately returned to politics after the war, running an unsuccessful bid for the United States Senate. He practiced law, and remained active in local political activities opposing Republican Reconstruction. In 1876, he won a seat in the Mississippi legislature and remained there until 1882, when he received an appointment as a district judge. One of his final political acts was as a delegate to Mississippi’s 1890 constitutional convention, which reinstituted many discriminatory policies against African Americans.
Featherston was married to Elizabeth McEwen and had seven children. He died in 1891 and is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Ben Wynne, “Winfield Scott Featherston,” Mississippi Encyclopedia)

Richard L. Watson was an attorney and Confederate soldier from Mississippi.

Born on January 12, 1826, in Tennessee, he moved to Mississippi some time before 1860. After the Civil War broke out in 1861, he was commissioned a captain in the Mississippi militia, eventually commanding Company I, Eighteenth Cavalry Battalion. Following the end of the war, Watson practiced law in Holly Springs, Mississippi. In the 1870s, he operated a law firm with Winfield S. Featherston and T. W. Harris. Watson passed away on September 7, 1878, during a yellow fever epidemic.

He was married to Amanda Bradford, who died ten days later during the same epidemic. The couple had at least one child, which died in infancy. Watson is buried at Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.
(FindaGrave; 1860 U.S. Census for Holly Springs, Mississippi, Roll M653_587, Page 160; The Comet, Jackson, MS, December 27, 1879; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, September 25, 1878)

note.p: William Matthew Strickland was a Confederate soldier and an attorney from Mississippi.

Born in Wake County, North Carolina, on January 1, 1823, Strickland moved to Mississippi as a boy with his family in 1837. Due to health issues, he temporarily left school as a teenager and worked in a mercantile business, owned by his brothers, in Chulahoma, Mississippi. In 1841, he was made supervisor of his father’s plantation. Eventually, he returned to professional studies and pursued a career in law. After apprenticing under two prominent jurists, Strickland began practicing law in the 1850s. When the Civil War broke out in 1861, he volunteered for Confederate service. He joined the Ninth Mississippi Infantry Regiment, and later served as a staff officer under various Confederate generals, including Braxton Bragg and John C. Pemberton. Strickland held the rank of major when the war ended in 1865.

After the war, Strickland returned to his law practice. He was involved in local politics, but largely in a support role rather than a candidate for public office. He did campaign to serve as a presidential elector in 1888. Strickland passed away on March 4, 1908. He was married twice, first to Martha Thompson, who died in 1863. He then married Eliza Jane Leake in 1867. He had at least eight children. Strickland is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.
(The Grenada Sentinel, Grenada, MS, October 20, 1888; FindaGrave)

Issac N. Osborn was a newspaper editor and Republican official in Louisiana and Mississippi after the Civil War.

His origins are unclear, but Osborn was originally from Indiana. He emerged in the public eye in Mississippi in the late 1860s as the newspaper editor of the Mail in Madison, Louisiana, and a resident of Vicksburg, Mississippi. He was openly Republican and was elected a Mississippi state representative in 1869. In 1872 he took the position as the Mississippi State Librarian, serving in that capacity until around 1875. Osborn then took the role of private secretary to Governor Adelbert Ames in the mid-1870s. During the latter part of the 1870s, Osborn served as inspector of customs and then ran for Mississippi legislature as a Republican in 1880. By the mid-1880s, his name no longer appeared in Mississippi newspapers regarding political or social activities, and his fate is unclear.

(Official Register of the United States, Containing a List of the Officres and Employees in the Civil, Military, and Naval Service, 1879, Vol. 1,, 158; The Weekly Mississippi Pilot, Jackson, MS, December 4, 1869; New Orleans Republican, New Orleans, LA, March 6, 1870; The Mississippi Press, Pascagoula, MS, April 27, 1877, October 29, 1880, and April 29, 1881)

Adelbert Ames served as a governor and U.S. senator of Mississippi during the Reconstruction era. He was born in East Thomaston (modern-day Rockland), Maine, in 1835. As a boy, Ames spent time working on various merchant vessels, receiving training in seamanship. He entered the United States Military Academy at West Point in 1856, graduating in May 1861, at the start of the Civil War. Commissioned as a second lieutenant, the young Ames was promoted to first lieutenant barely over a week later and served with the 5th U.S. Artillery during the battle of First Bull Run at Manassas, Virginia, on July 21, 1861. Despite being wounded in the leg, Ames stayed by his cannons. His actions at Bull Run led him to receive the brevet (honorary) rank of major and, in 1893 (more than thirty years later), the Medal of Honor.

Ames recovered from his wound and returned to the front lines in 1862, serving with distinction as an artillery officer during the Peninsula Campaign near Richmond. Seeking better promotion potential, Ames sought an infantry command. Through those efforts, in August 1862, he received command of the 20th Maine Infantry Regiment, and led that unit in combat during the Battle of Fredericksburg in December 1862. In May 1863, he volunteered to serve as a staff officer for Major General George G. Meade, which helped him achieve the rank of brigadier general that month. With this promotion, Ames left the 20th Maine to his second-in-command, Lieutenant Colonel Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain, who gained great fame commanding the regiment at Little Round Top during the Battle of Gettysburg in July 1863. Ames’ own performance at Gettysburg was highly praised, as his division successfully defended the Union position at Cemetery Hill.

After Gettysburg, Ames’ division was transferred to the Department of the South. Over the next two years, he commanded Union troops during campaigns in Florida, South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia. He received a brevet promotion to major general for his actions at Fort Fisher, North Carolina, in March 1865.

After the Civil War, Ames became involved in federal Reconstruction efforts. In 1868, he was appointed the provisional governor of Mississippi. Ames proved sympathetic to the plight of African Americans in the south. He sought to protect Black civil rights and appointed Mississippi’s first African American public officials. In 1870, after Mississippi was readmitted into the Union, Ames ran for U.S. senator for the state as a Republican and won. He served in that capacity from February 1870 to January 1874, achieving the reputation as a strong public speaker. While serving as a senator in Washington, D.C., Ames met and married Blanche Butler, daughter of Union general Benjamin F. Butler, under whom Ames had served during the war. Ames and his wife had six children over the course of their marriage.

In 1873, Ames ran for governor of Mississippi. His chief rival was James L. Alcorn, a former Confederate general who had been a Whig before the Civil War and joined the Republican Party afterwards. Ames won the election and worked diligently to improve Mississippi’s financial and social situation. In 1874, Democrats in Mississippi coordinated a campaign of violence against African Americans and white Republicans in the state, to secure political control in Mississippi. Unable to militarily suppress the white supremacist terror campaign, Ames signed a truce with Democratic leaders in Mississippi to reduce the violence and allow a peaceful election. Groups of white supremacists abandoned the truce and resumed their intimidation tactics against Republicans and Black Mississippians during the following elections, leading to a surge of Democratic politicians taking office.

In 1876, the conservative Democrat majority in the Mississippi legislature tried to impeach Ames and many other Republican officials with trumped up charges of corruption. Despite a strong political force against him, Ames’ critics were unable to provide any evidence of impropriety. Nevertheless, because impeachment was politically driven, Ames could see that his future as governor was over and any effort on his part to legally defend himself would be personally and financially taxing. He and his attorneys reached an agreement with Democratic leaders to resign his office in exchange for dropping the legal charges. On March 29, 1876, after Democrats cancelled their legal proceedings, Ames vacated his position.

Ames left Mississippi and went into business in Minnesota with his father and brother. A short time later, he relocated to New York City and then Massachusetts, overseeing mills and various business interests. When the Spanish-American War erupted in 1898, Ames volunteered for service and was appointed brigadier general of volunteers. Although over sixty years old, Ames joined the field campaign in Cuba and performed well.
Ames resumed his business ventures in the early twentieth century. He lived until 1933, dying at age 97. He is buried in Lowell, Massachusetts.
(Wikipedia)

Orlando Davis was an attorney, politician, and judge in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born on September 13, 1813, in Virginia, Davis moved to Ripley, Mississippi, as a young man. He studied law and became a successful attorney in Tippah County. By the 1840s he was active in public and political circles, and ran for state legislature as a Whig. He was a leading Union delegate to conventions in Tennessee and Mississippi held during the national political debate over the Compromise of 1850 and the future of slavery in federal territories gained after the Mexican-American War. Davis continued to be a Union and compromise politician through the 1850s, supporting the Constitutional Union candidate John Bell during the 1860 presidential election. However, after the election of Abraham Lincoln, Davis was a delegate to Mississippi secession convention and ultimately supported the state’s separation from the Union.

Davis remained in his home town of Ripley and practiced law during much of the Civil War. He provided moral and subsistence support for Confederate troops, being credited with delivering supplies to Mississippi troops in the field. After the war, he served as a circuit court judge. Davis died on August 4, 1898, at the age of 84. He was married to Martha McGee and had at least one child. Davis is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; The Semi-Weekly Leader, Brookhaven, MS, August 10, 1898; Holly Springs Gazette, April 6, 1844; The Ripley Advertiser, Ripley, MS, March 2, 1844; The Semi-Weekly Mississippi Free Trader, Natchez, MS, June 20, 1843; Flag of the Union, Jackson, MS, September 12, 1851; The Weekly Mississippian, Jackson, MS, August 8, 1860; The Weekly Mississippi Pilot, Jackson, MS, August 20, 1870)

James Thornton Fant was an attorney and judge in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born in Alabama on November 8, 1838, Fant graduated from the University of Mississippi in the late 1850s and became a practicing attorney in Holly Springs, Mississippi. When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Fant volunteered for Confederate service and served in the Ninth Mississippi Infantry Regiment. He was promoted to lieutenant in 1862 and was wounded during the Battle of Munfordville, Kentucky, in September 1862.

After the war he was appointed a district attorney and served in that role for several years in the 1870s. Fant also ran a law firm with his brother, Arthur Fant, and established a good reputation for his legal skills. In 1890, he was appointed circuit judge, to fill the vacancy left by the death of William Rogers. He served for two years and then resigned in 1892. He passed away on August 21, 1895. Fant was married to Clara M. Clayton and had at least one child, who died in infancy. Fant is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; Dunbar Rowland, The Official and Statistical Register of the State of Mississippi, 1908, 593; Alfred E. Fant, Fant genealogy, Entry 920; The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, March 20, 1878; The Semi-Weekly Leader, Brookhaven, MS, August 14, 1890; The State Ledger, Jackson, MS, September 20, 1892)

Nelson Green Gill was a U.S. soldier, Freedman's Bureau agent, and Republican state Representative for Mississippi during Reconstruction.

Born on November 1, 1830 in Hanover, Oneida County, New York, Gill enlisted in the U.S. Army in the 33rd Illinois Infantry with the outbreak of the Civil War in 1861. He was a member of Comapny B and was discharged carrying a rank of Captain on September 23, 1863.

After the war, Gill relocated to Holly Springs, Marshall County, Mississippi where he served as postmaster and was appointed sheriff. He also joined the Board of Supervisors and served as a Freedman's Bureau agent, taking an active role in promoting Black rights. This work led to at least one assassination attempt on his life. Gill and his wife Martha M. Gill organized a school for Black children in Holly Springs in the 1870s, and he served as Marshall County's Representative to the Mississippi House of Representatives in 1874 and 1875. In 1879, Gill relocated to Kansas, settling near the city of Emporia, where he maintained an active role in local politics, but in 1882 he moved to San Bernardino, California, where he became the county sheriff and was later appointed postmaster.

Gill was married to Martha Minerva "Minnie" (Whitford) Gill. The pair had at least three children, including one boy and two girls. Martha M. Gill applied for a pension on May 5, 1892 in California and is listed as a widow; however, Nelson Green Gill died on October 11, 1903 in San Bernardino, California. He is buried in the Pioneer Memorial Cemetery in San Bernardino.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Holly Springs, MS 1870 Census Record; Martha M. Gill, Pension Application, California, May 5, 1892; Nelson G Gill, U.S. Civil War Soldiers Records and Profiles, 1861-1865)

note.p: George Washington Albright was an African American farmer teacher, and politician in Mississippi during the nineteenth century.

Born enslaved on August 15, 1846, near Holly Springs, Mississippi, Albright worked as a farm laborer, but received some education from his mother, an enslaved kitchen worker who had listened to the lessons taught to the white children in her master’s house. He was liberated by Union forces during the Civil War and joined the Union League during the latter part of the war to support and expand Republican Party principles and Black civil rights in Mississippi.

After the Civil War, Albright attended school to further his education. He married Maria Hale in 1869 and had at least one child. He became active in state politics in the early 1870s and won election to the Mississippi State Senate, serving from 1874 to 1878. Shortly after his term ended, and in part due to increase Ku Klux Klan violence against Black Mississippians, Albright moved away from Mississippi and to Chicago before settling in Kansas by 1880. Records indicate he was married to a different woman by this point, by the name of Josephine Hardy, who was sometimes listed as white on censuses. He remained active in politics and public life, and continued to move every few years, including to California and Colorado. Albright died in 1944 at nearly 98 years old. He is buried in Mountain View Cemetery in Pueblo, Colorado.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; “George Washington Albright,” Against All Odds: The first Black legislators in Mississippi)

Currently located in Marshall County, Holly Springs was founded in 1836 in what was then Monroe County. When Marshall County was created on March 1, 1836, Holly Springs became its county seat. (Rowland, Mississippi, 874; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in central Mississippi, Leake County was established on December 23, 1833 from Madison and Rankin counties. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

"The crime of illegally entering a building and stealing things." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The crime of taking something that does not belong to you, but not in a way that involves force or the threat of force." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Having officially been found guilty of a crime in a law court." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"If someone who has committed a crime is pardoned, that person is officially forgiven and their punishment is stopped." (Cambridge Dictionary)"An act of mercy by a person in authority toward someone who has committed a crime, esp. by reducing a punishment." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"An occasion when someone is allowed to leave prison, etc." (Cambridge Dictionary)

"In law, a sentence is the punishment for a crime ordered by a trial court after conviction in a criminal procedure, normally at the conclusion of a trial. A sentence may consist of imprisonment, a fine, or other sanctions." (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: "Someone who owns or takes care of a farm, especially as a business." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who specializes in educating," spanning from grade school teachers to administrators. (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to calculate the tax that a person or business has to pay." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is in charge of a trial in a court and decides how a person who is guilty of a crime should be punished, or who makes decisions on legal matters." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A member of the police force." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Someone whose job is to give advice to people about the law and speak for them in court." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A member of a group of people who together have the power to make laws." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who is elected or chosen to lead the government of a town or city." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A person who works in an office, dealing with records or performing general office duties." (Cambridge Dictionary)

“Someone who works in an office, writing letters, making phone calls, and arranging meetings for a person or for an organization.” (Cambridge Dictionary) CWRGM includes people who perform administrative assistance under this tag, but we do not include government positions that incorporate the word secretary, such as Secretary of State, under this subject tag.
"A place where trials and other legal cases happen, or the people present in such a place." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"A court of equity in some US states." (Cambridge Dictionary)

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of the State of Mississippi consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, state treasurer, state comptroller, commissioner of agriculture, commissioner of insurance, the Mississippi Public Service Commission, the Mississippi Transportation Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

"Mississippi State Penitentiary, also known as Parchman Farm, is a maximum-security prison farm located in unincorporated Sunflower County, Mississippi, in the Mississippi Delta region. Occupying about 28 square miles (73 km2) of land, Parchman is the only maximum security prison for men in the state of Mississippi, and is the state's oldest prison." (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: This term refers to the relation, often but not always wives and children, of a person imprisoned in a civilian institution, ranging from jails to penitentiaries.

The term "enslavers" includes any person (male and female) who enslaved one or more of the more than 12.5 million people sold into the United States' race-based system of human chattel slavery between the 16th and 19th centuries. Enslavers used terms like "master," "owner," or "slaveholder" to imply a natural hierarchy within slavery and/or to imply that certain members of society were more capable than others. CWRGM, along with many other historical and archival resources, instead adopts the term "enslaver" to underscore the active effort on the part of enslavers to create and perpetuate a system of bondage over equally capable human beings deserving of the same natural rights (National Park Service).

Impoverished people are those who lack "a usual or socially acceptable amount of money or material possessions," or alternately those who "lack the means to satisfy their basic needs (Britannica). This definition, necessarily subjective and broad, indicates that what one person or society deems "socially acceptable" or what constitutes "basic needs" is malleable.

Similarly, impoverished people in the United States in the nineteenth century did not fit one specific category. The rise of industrialism produced an increased number of impoverished people in the U. S., particularly within large urban centers. European immigrants in cities in the East, and Chinese immigrants on the West Coast, and African Americans in the South were disproportionately affected by poverty. Regionally, the highest number of impoverished people came from the U. S. South, where "both whites and African Americans struggled with debt, low cotton prices, laws favorable to employers and creditors, paltry alternatives, and the general post war devastation" (Encyclopedia of the United States in the Nineteenth Century, Vol. 2, 547).

Racism and nativism among employers and employees also made economic advancement more difficult for people of color and immigrants. However, the impoverished made up a comparatively low percentage of Mississippi's antebellum population, given its low number of immigrants and even native residents, lack of industrialization and urbanization, and mobility of those that were impoverished (Mississippi Encyclopedia). Many reform organizations throughout the country took the lead in fighting poverty in the nineteenth century, while state and federal governments by the end of the century also developed its own institutional responses. The status of being impoverished has always carried negative connotations in American history, so CWRGM uses the tag "Impoverished people" to emphasize the personhood of those in poverty rather than their social status.

The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

div.p: [note] 1/28/75 [/note]

To His Excellency
A. Ames Govenor

The undersigned your Petitions beg respectfully to represent that at the March Term of the Circuit Court for Marshall Co 1874, Robert Hilliard and Squire Wooten were Convicted of the crime of Burglary & Grand Larceny.

That the offence (in particular) of which they were convicted was the Entering of a farmers Smoke House by night, and carrying away food and provisions to the amount of about the value of Two Hundred Dollars That the said Squire Wooten and Robert Hilliard are both men of large and very dependent families. Their familes consisting of one aged woman, their two wifes and eleven small children. Since the Conviction of the above named Hilliard & Wooten their families have been allmost entirely dependent on the Charity of their neighbors for support.

In view of the foregoing facts (as represented to us by parties who are ^in^ Every way worthy of belief,) and believing that the parties have allready suffered sufficiently for the Extent of the crime Committed, we have seen it proper to ask that your Excellency will use such power as possessed of by Law to the End that the said Hilliard & Wooten may be released from the State Penitentiary & restored to their liberty

John. S. Benton
former Owner & employer

I cannot, without violating a General rule, which I deem it proper to observe in the interest of law and justice, sign this, or any other petition for pardon. But I feel free to say, that inasmuch as the foregoing is signed by many of the leading and best citizens of Holly Springs and vicinity I think it ought to have great weight with the Governor.

I fully concur in the above remarks of Judge Davis, and think that a petition signed by such names as this, should have great might with the Executive, The families of the convicts I understand are in distress & greatly need their services, While therefore, as a rule I never recommend Executive Clemency, still in this case, I hope as favorable Consideration will be given as is possible under the circumstances

Jas T. Fant
